elements.text: PART ONE
SCENE 1. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
FX: IT’S 1963. COMPUTERS HUM AND BLEEP. MUTTERING AND THROAT-
CLEARING OF ANXIOUS, CHAIN-SMOKING SCIENTISTS AND MILITARY. A
IS BLEEPING A LACK-OF-SIGNAL TONE.
This is Baikonur control calling Vostok seven. Do you read? I repeat. This is Baikonur control calling Vostok seven.
Why isn’t she responding?
I don’t know. Weather interference, radiation from the Van Allen Belt, could be anything. We are stumbling blindly into the — (dark)
FX: SHE’S INTERRUPTED BY A RESPONSE VIA RADIO. HEAVY IN STATIC
BUT CLEAR ENOUGH SO WE CAN MAKE OUT THE WORDS. BRIEF DELAY.
CALL VIA RADIO ENDS WITH A BEEP.
(VIA RADIO) This is Cosmonaut Talanov, receiving you loud and clear.
FX: GENERAL RELIEF, SIGHS AND SOME APPLAUSE FROM SCIENTISTS.
What’s your status?
(VIA RADIO) All systems functioning normally. Is that you, Larisa?
Yes. You gave me quite a fright, and dragged me out of bed. How are you feeling?
(VIA RADIO) I feel fine, very fine. Heart-rate one hundred and ten. I ama little nervous, I think.
That’s just to be expected. Prepare to make lunar orbit insertion burn in twelve minutes, from now.
(VIA RADIO) Twelve minutes, check.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 3
You have two minutes until radio silence. When you become the first person ever to set eyes on the far side of the moon.
FX: MOVE CONTINUOUSLY INTO THE CAPSULE DURING THE ABOVE LINE.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 4
SCENE 2. INT. CAPSULE.
FX: INSIDE THE CAPSULE, EERIE SILENCE. MARINKA IS WEARING A
HELMET SO HER BREATHING AND AIR VENTILATION IS VERY CLOSE.
Looking forward to getting some peace and quiet.
(VIA RADIO) Do you have a visual on the lunar surface yet?
(STRUGGLES TO MOVE) Not yet. It is just black outside. Like the nights back in Irkutsk.
FX: DURING THIS LINE MOVE BACK TO MISSION CONTROL.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 5
SCENE 3. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
You should be flying into daylight side in just over a minute. Don’t forget to take some photographs for us. Please commence final system check.
(VIA RADIO) Commencing system check.

This is an historic day, Miss Petrov! The latest in a long line of Soviet achievements. After Laika, the first animal in space, Yuri Gagarin, the first man in space, and Valentina Tereshkova, the first woman, now, the first human being to orbit the moon: Cosmonaut Marinka Talanov, on November the tenth, ninety sixty- three!
(QUIET) Another propaganda victory for Comrade Khrushchev.
I’m sorry, I didn’t quite catch that, Miss — (Petrov)
FX: HE’S INTERRUPTED BY ANOTHER RADIO MESSAGE.
(VIA RADIO)
Baikonur Control.. I have malfunction on capsule life support. I repeat. Malfunction. (FX: STATIC INCREASES) (System shutdown)
What? What sort of malfunction? (BEAT) Marinka?!
FX: INTERFERENCES INCREASES, FOLLOWING LINES ONLY OCCASTONALLY
INTELLIGIBLE. ALARMED MUTTERING AND BUSTLE AMONGST SCIENTISTS.
(VIA RADIO)
. Complete system shutdown... capsule power failure... no secondary supply... cockpit pressure dropping to nought point five. I can’t — (breathe) My God! (BOWSH-HAY-MOY )
FX: LINK GOES TO STATIC, THEN BLEEPING OF NO SIGNAL.
It’s no good. We’ve lost her.
Is she dead?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 6
We have no way of knowing, not for another forty-five minutes. The capsule has now passed behind the moon.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 7
4. EXT. STEPPE.
FX: ICY WIND. TARDIS LANDS, DOOR OPENS, OUR HEROES EMERGE.
(SHIVER) I don’t believe it! It’s even colder outside!
Yes. The circuit that maintains the TARDIS’s temperature appears to have, er... stopped working.
Thanks, Doctor. If you hadn’t told me, however would I have guessed?
Sarcasm will hardly improve our predicament, Peri.
So why haven’t you just replaced this circuit? Oh, no, don’t tell me. You don’t have a replacement.
Not as such, no. I should’ve learned my lesson last time.
Last time? This has happened before?
Once before, yes.
So what did you do that time?
As I recall I spent several months travelling across China with Marco Polo.
So not a lot of help to us now?
No. But given time, and suitable facilities, I should be able to effect a repair.
Good luck finding an electrical store because, in case you hadn’t noticed, we’re standing in the middle of a desert!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 8
Yes. I take your point.
Where are we, anyway? Looks like Nevada, or Colorado.
Not sure. Unfortunately the TARDIS’s navigational systems are, er... also dependent upon this circuit.
You mean we can’t leave?
I’m afraid not.
Right, well, I don’t know about you, but I’m going back inside. To see if there’s anything I can burn to keep warm.
Yes, that might be — (SEES SOMETHING) No, wait. Peri!
What?
Over there. Lights. Now where do I keep my telescope? In my other coat? No. (FX: LOCATES AND OPENS TELESCOPE) Ah-ha!
What is it?
A car, about a mile away. A jeep! It appears to have crashed.
But if the headlights are still on, it must’ve only just happened. There might be injured people inside.
Precisely. And we can hardly leave them out here to freeze to
death. Come on, Peri! We’re needed!
FX: THEY HEAD OFF.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 9
5. EXT. STEPPE.
FX: DOCTOR AND PERI APPROACH CAR. ITS ENGINES ARE STEAMING.
I don’t get it. Why did it crash into a ditch, on an empty, straight road, with nothing else for miles around?
I don’t think it did. Not with any force, at least. The bonnet hasn’t buckled, nor have the bumpers.
The ‘bumpers’? Oh, you mean the fenders.
Yes. The ‘fenders’. (PULLS) Door’s jammed... Give me a moment.
EFFORT
FX: HE OPENS A DOOR.
(SMALL YELP OF SURPRISE) Is he dead?
I’m afraid so. And the woman in the passenger seat too.
They’ve been shot.
(GRIM) Indeed. Peri, can you take a look in the back, while I try to find out who these people were...
If you insist.
FX: PERI PULLS BACK A TARPAULIN AND CLIMBS IN.
(CLAMBERING) Oh my... there’s another woman here, well, she’s about my age. Or was. She... she’s been shot too. Wearing a
military uniform, with a hammer and sickle. She’s Russian!
FX: DOCTOR PULLS OFF JACKETS, DISCOVERS PAPERS.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 10
Or Soviet, at least. According to their identity papers, these people were Doctor Kristina Pushkin, and Doctor Grigory Kalashnikov.
Kalashnikov? Like the rifles?
Like the rifles. He was an astrophysicist, born in nineteen- nineteen. She was a physician, born in nineteen forty. What about your woman?
I don’t know, she doesn’t seem to have any ID on her. It’s a bit hard to tell in this light.
Yes. It is getting dark, isn’t it. It’1ll be night soon. Oh well, needs must...
FX: HE REMOVES THE BODIES’ COATS
Doctor, what are you doing?
Taking their coats. They no longer have any need of them, whereas they may prevent us from developing hypothermia.
Are you sure that’s wise? We can always get some more clothes back in the... (TRAILS OFF, SEEN SOMETHING)
Yes, but the TARDIS is a mile away, and if we are where I think we are, then night falls very quickly.
(QUIET BUT INSISTENT) Doctor.
Yes?
FX: QUIET TICKING, WHIRRING NOISE FROM NOW ON.
Some sticks of dynamite covered in wires making a ticking noise, that would probably be a bomb, wouldn’t it?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 11
Yes.
It’s under one of the seats... and the clock says there’s about
twenty seconds left.
Peri, get out of there now!
FX: PERI DOES.
(CLAMBERING) You don’t have to tell me twice! Can you defuse Lt?
FX: DOCTOR CLAMBERS OUT.
Not in this light, there’s no time. We have to run. Run!
FX: THEY RUN. WE NO LONGER HEAR TICKING AS WE TRAVEL WITH THEM.
(RUNNING) Back to the TARDIS?
RUNNING) Just as far away as we can, we don’t have — (any
FX: BOMB EXPLODES DESTROYING JEEP
& PERI
KNOCKED OVER BY BLAST
FX: JEEP ON FIRE IN MID-DISTANCE.
(HELPING HER UP) Peri, are you all right?
(GETTING UP) Grazed knees but basically fine. You?
Oh, you know me, I’m indestructible. Here, take this coat.
FX: SHE DOES, WRAPPING UP.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 12
But why plant a bomb, if everyone in the car was already dead?
I think their intention was to remove any evidence of foul
play.
Right. To make it look like they were killed in the crash!
Precisely. And now there’s nothing left to suggest otherwise. Just three thoroughly cremated corpses.
There were nearly five.
Yes. And nothing piques my curiosity like a brush with death.
Don’t tell me. You want to find out who did this and bring them to justice?
Well, don’t you?
Sure. We can do it first thing, tomorrow. But in the meantime, how about we get back to the TARDIS and — (light a)
No time for that, Peri. Look! Someone’s coming.
FX: DISTANT VEHICLE APPROACHING.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 13
6. INT. JEEP. (IN MOTION
FX: INSIDE THE JEEP, MOTOR RUNNING. RADIO SWITCHES ON.
Captain, this is Sergeant Kurakin reporting, over.
(VIA RADIO) I hear you, Sergeant. What is it? Over.
Sir, I’m on the Kyzylorda road, and there is a plume of smoke. It is a Gaz sixty-nine on fire, over.
(VIA RADIO) Any sign of its occupants, over?
No, they must’ve been killed in the — no, wait. I can see two of them, they’re alive! Over.
(VIA RADIO) Then bring them in, Sergeant. Out.
FX: RADIO OFF. JEEP PULLS UP, ENGINE STILL TICKING OVER.
(CALLING OUT) You all right, out there?
(APPROACHING) Hello, yes! I wonder if you could help us —
It’s all right, we’ve been expecting you. (FX: DOOR OPENS) Get in.
What?
In the back. Unless you want to die of exposure. It gets chilly out here on the steppe. Low as minus forty, some nights.
Then we’re very fortunate you found us.
FX: DOCTOR AND PERI CLAMBER IN. CLOSE DOORS.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 14
Yes, this has really been our lucky night.
What happened to you?
Ah, we swerved to avoid another vehicle on the road, and, well, you can guess the rest.
There was no-one else in the car?
No, just the two of us. You said we were expected?
That is why Captain Kozlov sent me out here, to find you when you did not arrive on schedule.
Of course, yes. I’m very glad you found us, Sergeant...?
Kurakin. Sergeant Leonid Kurakin. You have no other belongings?
No, I’m afraid we only have the clothes we’re wearing, everything else was destroyed in the fire.
Then there is no point in us remaining here.
FX: HE GUNS ENGINE, DRIVES.
(OVER ENGINE) How long, do you think, until we get there?
(OVER ENGINE) To the Cosmodrome? About half an hour. Maybe give you a few glasses of Stoli to warm you up, eh?
Sounds great. (WHISPER) Doctor. What the hell are we doing, pretending to be, who was it? Doctor Kalashnikov and Doctor Pushkin?
(WHISPER) Staying alive. We have their identity papers,
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 15
everything we need to prove we are who we say we are.
(WHISPER) Yes, and what if we meet someone who knew the real Kalashnikov and Pushkin?
(WHISPER) That may pose a small problem, I admit.
(WHISPER) A small problem? We’re in Soviet Russia. If they find out where I’m from, they’1ll have me shot!
(WHISPER) Then I recommend you don’t tell them. And this isn’t Soviet Russia.
(WHISPER) It isn’t? Then where the hell are we?
(WHISPER) Kazakhstan.
(FORGETTING TO WHISPER) Kazakhstan!
Hey, what are you muttering about back there?
We were just talking about your country, what a beautiful place rh 28%
It’s not my country, I’m Kirov born and bred. I wouldn’t spend
a Single second in this dump if I didn’t have to.
FX: THEY DRIVE ON.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 16
SCENE 7. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
FX: SCIENTISTS FRETTING IN B/G, CHATTER.
If Talanov is dead, you know who will be held responsible, Miss Petrov.
At the moment I’m rather more concerned for the well-being of my cosmonaut than my career. If she has died then I’m sure you will make sure no-one ever learns about it.
(APPROACHING) Excuse me, General Leonov?
Yes, Captain?
The two scientists from Moscow have arrived.
What scientists? I asked for — (no)

Not my idea, Miss Petrov. They were sent here on the orders of the presidium to share their “specialist knowledge”. Captain. Have them brought here without delay. We may soon be in need of their assistance.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 17
8. INT. JEEP.
FX: JEEP IS HALTED, ENGINE TURNING. DRIVER’S DOOR CLOSED.
(CLIMBING BACK IN) Nearly there. I have been ordered to take you straight to mission control.
Excellent news, looking forward to it!
FX: JEEP DRIVES ON.
(WHISPER) Mission control? What is this? The Soviet Cape Canaveral?
(WHISPER) More or less. If I know my history — as I invariably do — this is the Baikonur Cosmodrome. A town built in the middle of the Kazakh steppe.
(WHISPER) Modelled on downtown Detroit, by the look of it.
(WHISPER) Yes, well, it probably looks less foreboding during daylight.
(WHISPER) You think? Doctor, that guy you found, how old was he?
(WHISPER) Mid-forties, why?
(WHISPER) Born in nineteen-nineteen — which makes it the mid- Sixties. The height of the cold war!
(WHISPER) So?
(WHISPER) So right now this is one of the most high-security — not to mention dangerous — places on the planet! Particularly
for someone of my personal circumstances.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 18
(WHISPER) Then you should be grateful, Kristina, for a chance to see how the other half live!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 19
9. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
Capsule emerging from moon shadow... now.
FX: LACK OF SIGNAL BLEEPING.
This is Baikonur control calling Vostok seven. Do you read? I repeat. This is Baikonur control calling Vostok seven.
FX: BLEEPING.
Nothing. We’ve lost her. You’ve lost her.
I’m not giving up yet. Check transceiver feedback.
FX: RADIO STATIC TURNS INTO BRIEF, SHRILL BURST OF FEEDBACK.
Transceiver feedback established.
What does that mean?
It means she can hear us, even if we can’t hear her. (INTO RADIO) This is Baikonur control calling Vostok seven! Do you read? Marinka? (SHE CONTINUES IN B/G)
FX: DOOR OPENS, DOCTOR, PERI, ALEXEI AND LEONID ENTER.
Ah, this would be mission control, would it? Fascinating!
Sir, the two scientists from Moscow.
Thank you, Captain Kozlov. Welcome, comrades. I am General Leonov, commanding officer of the Cosmodrome.
Pleased to meet you, general.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 20
I understand you had some difficulty on your journey —
Never mind that. By the look of it you’re having trouble regaining contact with one of your space capsules, am I right?
You are correct. Allow me to introduce Miss Larisa Petrov, our chief scientist.
General, this is hardly the time, I am the middle of a very delicate operation —
These are the scientists sent by the presidium. Doctor Grigory Kalashnikov. And Doctor Kristina Pushkin.
You’re Doctor Kalashnikov? And Doctor Pushkin?
Yes. Why? Is there some problem with that?
(SARCASTIC) No, of course not. What could be more helpful than having two scientists I’ve never heard of interrupting my work?
What indeed? Tell me, how long has it been since you last made contact with your cosmonaut?
Fifty minutes. The capsule has passed behind the moon, you see.
Has it really? How very impressive.
And just before we lost contact with her, Cosmonaut Talanov reported a fault with the life support system.
I see. And now she’s not answering her radio?
That’s right. But we have transceiver feedback, so — (we)
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 21
- You know you’re getting through. Then I suggest you give your cosmonaut a wake-up call.
What do you mean?
Disengage the filter and amplify the signal oscillation to create a burst of feed-back, as loud and high-pitched as possible.
It’s worth a try. Amplify signal oscillation.
FX: FEEDBACK VIA RADIO INCREASES, BECOMING A WHINE, THEN CUTS
OUT. WE HEAR A VOICE VIA THE RADIO, NOT IMMEDIATELY CLEAR.
(VIA RADIO) (WAKING) What is it? What — where am I?
FX: JUBILATION IN MISSION CONTROL
She’s alive!
It seems this is your lucky day, Miss Petrov.
For all of us. (INTO RADIO) Cosmonaut Talanov. What’s your status? Report?
FX: NOTE MARINKA IS LEAVING HER RADIO CHANNEL OPEN ALL THE
TIME, NOT SWITCHING IT OFF BETWEEN CONTACTS AS BEFORE (NO BEEP AT END OF LINES VIA RADIO). IT STILL DROPS OUT FREQUENTLY AND
TIME DELAY.
(VIA RADIO) Who is this? Who are you?
This is Baikonur Control. Are you all right?
(VIA RADIO) (BECOMING MORE AGITATED) I do not understand. I can’t see you. Where are you?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 22
You reported a fault with the life-support. Please give details.
(VIA RADIO) I do not understand. Where am I? What am I doing here?
FX: DURING THIS LINE MOVE TO CAPSULE.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 23
10. INT. CAPSULE.
(VIA RADIO) It’s all right, Marinka. You’re safe. Please try to stay calm.
Marinka? Who is Marinka? Who are you?
(VIA RADIO) Larisa Pushkin. You must remember me?
No. I don’t know who you are. But you have to let me out of here!
FX: DURING THIS MOVE BACK TO MISSION CONTROL
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 24
11. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
(VIA RADIO) Please let me out of here. Where am I? I don’t want to be here anymore. Why have you done this to me? (REPEATS IN B/G AD LIB)
What’s the matter with her?
You don’t know? I thought you were supposed to be the expert?
I was consulting my colleague. Doctor Kalashnikov?
Some sort of stress-induced dissociative disorder, perhaps?
Yes, that’s what I thought. (BLUFFING) Short-term memory loss, probably the result of latent claustrophobia.
Or brain damage. If there was a problem with the life-support, and she suffered cerebral hypoxia...
That seems more likely. Cosmonaut Talanov was extensively tested. She is not claustrophobic.
(VIA RADIO) Help me. Please. Let me out. Let me out!
Well she is now. May I? (INTO RADIO) Hello. This is the Doctor.
(VIA RADIO) Who are you?
A friend. Who wants to help.
(VIA RADIO) You will let me out of here?
As soon as I can, but I need you to help me first.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 25
(VIA RADIO) No. Let me out first! Let me out now!
She’s not even aware that she’s floating in space.
Listen to me. I need you to tell me who you are. What’s your name?
(VIA RADIO) (INCREASING HYSTERIA) I don’t know. I don’t know. I don’t know!
You have to calm down. Breathe slowly, can you do that for me?
(VIA RADIO) Yes.. I breathe... slowly.
That’s good. Good. Now, just relax, keep calm, and everything will be all right. (OFF RADIO) Miss Pushkin, General Leonov. We have to bring her back to Earth right now.
Right now? She’s three hundred and fifty thousand kilometres
out. It will take at least three days for her to return home.
FX: FADE OUT.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 26
12. INT. CANTEEN.
FX: FADE IN. CUTLERY, SUBDUED CHATTER, PEOPLE COME AND GO,
MILITARY/CLASSICAL MUSIC ON RADIO.
Miss Pushkin? Mind if I join you?
No, not at all. Sergeant Kurakin, isn’t it?
Leonid, please call me Leonid.
Only if you call me... Kristina.
Kristina. Your quarters, they are comfortable?
Yeah, fine, thanks. Real home from home.
Doctor Kalashnikov, he is also comfortable?
I wouldn’t know. I’ve barely seen him these last three days. He’s spent most of it holed up with Miss Petrov.
You don’t mind, him spending all his time with another woman?
Why should I mind? Wait. You’re fishing, aren’t you?
Fishing?
Trying to find out if the Doctor and me are a couple.
Well? Are you?
No. He’s not my type. And the Doctor, well, I’m definitely not his type. He’s more interested in his work.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 27
And you? Are you also married to your work?
No, I’m not married, to my work or anyone else. What about you? Do you have a girl back in Kirov?
Ah, no. Just my parents. Where are you from? Your accent
suggests you are not from Russia.
No? Where does it suggest I come from?
Somewhere in the west, I think.
The west?
Yes. Poland. Or one of the Baltic states, Estonia, Latvia.
Latvia, yes, that’s right.
So how does a girl from Latvia end up at Moscow university?
FX: BUZZER ON THE PA SYSTEM SOUNDS
I’m sorry, if you will excuse me, I’m due back on guard duty.
Don’t forget to keep warm.
I’1l do my best. Kristina.
FX: HE GOES
(QUIETLY, TO HERSELF) You’ve still got it, Peri. Wherever you go in the universe, there’s always one. (FINDS SOMETHING) Hey, Leonid, you left something? Leonid. (READS) Doctor Pushkin...
FX: SHE OPENS LETTER, FINDS KEY, JANGLES IT.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 28
(QUIETLY) A key... “Research area four. One hour.”
FX: SHE GOES.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 29
13. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
FX: LARISA IN RADIO CONTACT WITH CAPSULE. SCIENTISTS IN B/G.
You see the red button in front of you?
(VIA RADIO) Red? What is red?
The large button. That will replenish your water supply. As I told you two hours ago.
FX: ENDS RADIO CONTACT.
It’s as if she is a simpleton.
No. She’s been deprived of her autobiographical memories.
Deprived?
(WHILST WORKING ON A GADGET) Something happened to her, on the far side of the moon. Something that affected her mind.
Doctor, what is that?
What?
That device you have been working on during my rest periods. Using my laboratory and equipment.
Oh, just a computer circuit. You don’t mind, do you?
No, but Captain Kozlov might. He’s paranoid about security, if he thought you were making a radio —
He might take me for a spy?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 30
Miss Petrov, Doctor Kalashnikov — it’s time.
Thank you. All right. Activate remote guidance system.
FX: REGULAR BLEEPING, COMPUTER NOISE, LIKE OLD SPECTRUM GAME.
Guidance system activated.
Prepare for lateral engine burn to correct course. One hundred percent for —
Eight seconds. Commencing, three, two, one... now.
Commencing lateral engine burn... (FX: BLEEPING CHANGES PITCH, THEN JUST STATIC.) My God. It’s not responding. It’s not responding!
FX: MILD CONSTERNATION.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 31
14. INT. CORRIDOR.
FX: PERI APPROACHES.
“Research area four. Authorised personnel only.”
FX: UNLOCKS DOOR. SHE ENTERS. FOOTSTEPS ECHO IN HANGAR. SHE’S
IN DARKNESS.
(QUIETLY) Hello? Is anyone there? Hello?
FX: SHE KEEPS ON WALKING, THEN HALTS.
Spacesuits? Empty spacesuits? (BEAT) I don’t believe it. They’ve only gone and built a —
FX: LIGHTS SLAM ON. THUNK! THUNK! THUNK!
Lunar landing module, Doctor Pushkin?
What is this, some sort of secret research project?
Of course. Didn’t you read the sign? Authorised personnel only. You are trespassing. In a restricted area.
I am a doctor, sent here on the authority of the presidium —
You don’t have to play games with me. I know who you really are.
You do?
I know you are not Doctor Kristina Pushkin. Despite what your identity papers may claim.
Then who am I?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 32
Who are you? Why, you are a spy, of course.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 33
15. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
FX: RADIO STILL NOT RESPONDING.
REWIRING CIRCUITS IN B/G
(TO SCIENTISTS) Keep trying. If the capsule enters the atmosphere at the wrong angle it will burn up or bounce back into space.
FX: MIKHAIL ENTERS.
Miss Petrov, what’s happening?
We've lost contact with the capsule during a critical moment —
And what is Doctor Kalashnikov doing?
Me? Spot of rewiring. You see, it appears the problem is at our end.
Our end?
(CLIMBS OUT FROM UNDER DESK) Our signal isn’t getting through. It’s not even being broadcast. (FX: PRESSING SWITCHES) But if I can re-route it through the second satellite dish —
What do you mean it’s not getting through? Another malfunction?
I suppose that’s a possibility. Seems a trifle unlikely, though.
Then what are you saying? It was sabotaged?
(FX: FINISHES) We have more important things to worry about right now. Miss Petrov, if you could try again.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 34
Activate guidance system.
Guidance system — responding!
FX: SCIENTISTS PLEASED.
So now what?
We have to calculate a new trajectory, but the computations will take an hour at least.
(FX: FRANTIC SCRIBBLING) Give me a few moments... Finished. Commence a twenty-second engine burn — now!
Commencing engine burn.
FX: RADIO REGAINED
(VIA RADIO) (TERRIFIED) What is happening? What are you doing? Help me!
It’s alright, we’re bringing you home.
(VIA RADIO) Home? No. I don’t like it. Let me out! Let me out!
We will, very soon. You don’t have much longer to wait.
(VIA RADIO) No. Let me out now. Please!
FX: RADIO CONTACT ENDS.
Doctor, where will the capsule come down?
By my reckoning about sixty kilometres due north of the cosmodrome, in just under an hour’s time.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 35
16. INT. RESEARCH AREA.
For the last time. I’m not a spy.
You must forgive my melodramatics. I know you are a spy, because I was the one who sent for you.
You sent for me?

LARISA: You see the red button in front of you?
MARINKA: (VIA RADIO) Red? What is red?
LARISA: The large button. That will replenish your water supply. As I told you two hours ago.
LARISA: It’s as if she is a simpleton.
DOCTOR: No. She’s been deprived of her autobiographical memories.
LARISA: Deprived?
DOCTOR: (WHILST WORKING ON A GADGET) Something happened to her, on the far side of the moon. Something that affected her mind.
LARISA: Doctor, what is that?
DOCTOR: What?
LARISA: That device you have been working on during my rest periods. Using my laboratory and equipment.
DOCTOR: Oh, just a computer circuit. You don’t mind, do you?
LARISA: No, but Captain Kozlov might. He’s paranoid about security, if he thought you were making a radio —
DOCTOR: He might take me for a spy?
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 30
SCIENTIST: Miss Petrov, Doctor Kalashnikov — it’s time.
LARISA: Thank you. All right. Activate remote guidance system.
SCIENTIST: Guidance system activated.
LARISA: Prepare for lateral engine burn to correct course. One hundred percent for —
DOCTOR: Eight seconds. Commencing, three, two, one... now.
SCIENTIST: Commencing lateral engine burn... (FX: BLEEPING CHANGES PITCH, THEN JUST STATIC.) My God. It’s not responding. It’s not responding!
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 31
PERI: “Research area four. Authorised personnel only.”
PERI: IN DARKNESS.
PERI: (QUIETLY) Hello? Is anyone there? Hello?
PERI: Spacesuits? Empty spacesuits? (BEAT) I don’t believe it. They’ve only gone and built a —
ALEXEI: Lunar landing module, Doctor Pushkin?
PERI: What is this, some sort of secret research project?
ALEXEI: Of course. Didn’t you read the sign? Authorised personnel only. You are trespassing. In a restricted area.
PERI: I am a doctor, sent here on the authority of the presidium —
ALEXEI: You don’t have to play games with me. I know who you really are.
PERI: You do?
ALEXEI: I know you are not Doctor Kristina Pushkin. Despite what your identity papers may claim.
PERI: Then who am I?
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 32
ALEXEI: Who are you? Why, you are a spy, of course.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 33
LARISA: (TO SCIENTISTS) Keep trying. If the capsule enters the atmosphere at the wrong angle it will burn up or bounce back into space.
MIKHAIL: Miss Petrov, what’s happening?
LARISA: We've lost contact with the capsule during a critical moment —
MIKHAIL: And what is Doctor Kalashnikov doing?
DOCTOR: Me? Spot of rewiring. You see, it appears the problem is at our end.
LARISA: Our end?
DOCTOR: (CLIMBS OUT FROM UNDER DESK) Our signal isn’t getting through. It’s not even being broadcast. (FX: PRESSING SWITCHES) But if I can re-route it through the second satellite dish —
MIKHAIL: What do you mean it’s not getting through? Another malfunction?
DOCTOR: I suppose that’s a possibility. Seems a trifle unlikely, though.
LARISA: Then what are you saying? It was sabotaged?
DOCTOR: (FX: FINISHES) We have more important things to worry about right now. Miss Petrov, if you could try again.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 34
LARISA: Activate guidance system.
SCIENTIST: Guidance system — responding!
MIKHAIL: So now what?
LARISA: We have to calculate a new trajectory, but the computations will take an hour at least.
DOCTOR: (FX: FRANTIC SCRIBBLING) Give me a few moments... Finished. Commence a twenty-second engine burn — now!
SCIENTIST: Commencing engine burn.
MARINKA: (VIA RADIO) (TERRIFIED) What is happening? What are you doing? Help me!
LARISA: It’s alright, we’re bringing you home.
MARINKA: (VIA RADIO) Home? No. I don’t like it. Let me out! Let me out!
DOCTOR: We will, very soon. You don’t have much longer to wait.
MARINKA: (VIA RADIO) No. Let me out now. Please!
MIKHAIL: Doctor, where will the capsule come down?
DOCTOR: By my reckoning about sixty kilometres due north of the cosmodrome, in just under an hour’s time.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 35
PERI: For the last time. I’m not a spy.
ALEXEI: You must forgive my melodramatics. I know you are a spy, because I was the one who sent for you.
PERI: You sent for me?
ALEXEI: I contacted the KGB with my suspicions. They told me to expect two agents posing as scientific experts from Moscow university.
PERI: What were these suspicions?
ALEXEI: I believed there was someone based in the cosmodrome who was passing on our research to a third party.
PERI: ‘Believed’?
ALEXEI: I found proof. Valentina Cherlin. She gained access to the restricted area, this place. I found her taking photographs. She had already passed on the blueprints for the lunar module.
PERI: Passed on to who?
ALEXEI: All I know is that they’re an agent working for the West. Valentina wouldn’t tell me any more than that.
PERI: Maybe she’1ll talk to me. Where is she?
ALEXEI: I don’t know. I locked her in my quarters, told her what would happen if she did not cooperate, but when I returned she had gone.
PERI: She escaped?
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 36
ALEXEI: Or the enemy agent came for her.
PERI: This Valentina, what is she like?
ALEXEI: She is small, attractive, about your age.
PERI: (REALISING) And she disappeared... just before I got here.
ALEXEI: I know I should have questioned her more, used force... but I couldn’t do it.
PERI: Why not?
ALEXEI: Because I loved her. That’s how she’d gained access to the restricted area, she had stolen my key. Valentina and I were lovers.
MIKHAIL: (VIA TANNOY)
MIKHAIL: Attention. All capsule recovery staff to go to departure point one. All medical staff on stand-by.
PERI: That’s me, I have to go.
ALEXEI: But you and Doctor Kalashnikov, you will find the traitor? And
ALEXEI: Valentina?
PERI: I can’t make any promises. But we’1ll do our best.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 37
LARISA: (INTO RADIO) Five kilometres to landing site.
DOCTOR: (OVER ENGINES) Larisa, there! Over there!
LARISA: (INTO RADIO) Have spotted capsule vapour trail. Parachute has successfully deployed. Repeat. Parachute has successfully
LARISA: deployed!
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 38
MIKHAIL: You can see the capsule itself? Over.
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Yes, it’s just hit the ground. Glowing hot but it appears undamaged. Over.
PERI: What’s going on?
MIKHAIL: Vostok seven’s returned to Earth.
PERI: It has? Where’s the Doctor?
MIKHAIL: With Miss Petrov, in the helicopter. What’s your status, over?
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Just coming in to land beside the capsule, over.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 39
JUMP: OUT, ALONG WITH SOME SOLDIERS.
LARISA: (OVER DIN) There it is, I can hardly believe it. The first man- made object to orbit the moon.
DOCTOR: (OVER DIN) Let’s save the congratulations until we’ve got Marinka out, shall we?
LARISA: If she’s still alive.
DOCTOR: Try the radio.
LARISA: This is Larisa Petrov calling Vostok seven. Can you hear me? Repeat. Can you hear me? Over.
MARINKA: (VIA RADIO) Please. Let me out. Let me out of here!
LARISA: She’s alive!
DOCTOR: Yes. It certainly sounds like it.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 40
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Cosmonaut Talanov is alive. I repeat. She’s alive! Over.
MIKHAIL: Well done, Miss Petrov. Never doubted you for a moment. Proceed
MIKHAIL: to open Vostok capsule. Over.
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Cutting hatch seals now, over.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 41
LARISA: Hatch seals have now been cut. Over.
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Then open the capsule. Get her out of there.
LARISA: Opening hatch.
LARISA: My God. I... I don’t believe it.
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) What is it? Miss Petrov? Report. Report.
LARISA: It’s absurd but.. Cosmonaut Talanov has gone. a dog inside her space suit!
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) A dog?
DOCTOR: And not just any dog.
LARISA: What?
DOCTOR: Don’t you recognise it? It’s Laika.
DOCTOR: END OF PART ONE
DOCTOR: Over.
DOCTOR: There is... there
DOCTOR: is
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 42

elements.text: PART TWO
22. EXT. STEPPE.
Opening hatch.
FX: HATCH OPENS.
My God. I... I don’t believe it.
(VIA RADIO) What is it? Miss Petrov? Report. Report.
It’s absurd but... Cosmonaut Talanov has gone. a dog inside her space suit!
(VIA RADIO) A dog?
And not just any dog.
What?
Don’t you recognise it? It’s Laika. (REPRISE
There is... there is
ENDS. )
But that’s ridiculous. Someone must have interfered with the capsule, put the dog in there as some sort of joke.
When? We saw it land. We were the first to reach it.
Well, what do you think’s happened?
Someone did interfere with the capsule. When it was on the far
side of the moon.
FX: RADIO CRACKLES
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 43
(VIA RADIO) Let me out. Please. Let me out.
It’s Marinka. She must still be in the capsule.
No. There’s no-one else in there.
(VIA RADIO) I can see you. Let me out.
Doctor, what are you doing?
(EFFORT) Removing her helmet — ah!
FX: HE DOES SO, RELEASE OF ATR
(VOICE AND RADIO) Thank you. (BREATHING DEEPLY) Whoever you are. Thank you.
The dog. It’s speaking. It’s speaking!
Yes. (TO LAIKA) Hello. I’m the Doctor. Tell me, how did you end up here?
I... don’t remember.
Do you remember being sent into space?
I remember being locked in a metal box. And then there was this screaming, crushing. I was so frightened. I thought I was going to die. And then I was alone. So alone...
I think that confirms it. This is Laika.
Yes, yes. That is what they called me. Laika. I am Laika!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 44
23. INT. MISSION CONTROL
Laika?
(VIA RADIO) I find it as hard to believe as you do, sir. Over.
All right. Have the capsule brought to the quarantine area. I’1ll tell the medical staff to get ready.
(VIA RADIO) Yes, sir.
Until further notice, no-one is to have any contact with the occupant of the capsule. The fewer people who know about this, the better. Over.
(VIA RADIO) But General, you have to allow me to stay with her. She’s alone, she’s afraid, she —
No, Doctor. You are not to speak to that animal again. Out.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 45
24. INT. LABORATORY/QUARANTINE ROOM
FX: AGITATED MONKEYS, DOGS, CATS MAKING NOISES AND RATTLING
CAGES. SCIENTISTS TRYING TO CALM THEM.
What on Earth’s got into the other animals?
I’m not sure, General. They’ve been like this ever since... the “Cosmonaut Talanov” dog was brought in.
Where is... she?
Through here.
FX: THEY ENTER ANOTHER ROOM, DOOR CLOSES, SHUTTING OUT SOUNDS
OF OTHER ANIMALS.
I’ve had her restrained on an operating table for examination purposes.
Who are you? Why have you done this to me? (STRAINS) Let me go!
We... er... We just want to find out about you. To work out what happened.
And what you’ve done with Cosmonaut Talanov.
You! I know you. You locked me into the metal box. It was you!
Seems she recognises you, General.
Then she’ll know what happens if she doesn’t obey.
No. Keep away from me! You left me to die!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 46
What have you done with Cosmonaut Talanov?
I don’t know!
Where is she? Where have you been these last six years?
I don’t know!
Maybe she genuinely doesn’t know, general. The amnesia —
She hasn’t forgotten me, Miss Petrov. She’1ll tell us what we want to know. One way or another.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 47
25. EXT. STREET.
FX: DOCTOR AND PERI TRUDGING THROUGH SNOW, TRAFFIC IN B/G.
Peri, let me get this straight. The Soviets have a prototype lunar landing module, hidden in a secret hangar?
Yeah. Just like the Neil Armstrong one, all ready to go.
And the real Kalashnikov and Pushkin were KGB spies, sent to locate an enemy agent who had been receiving confidential information from — what was her name?
Valentina Cherlin. The third girl we found, in the crashed car.
Yes. I think it’s safe to conclude the enemy agent murdered her in order to guarantee her silence.
But why kill Kalashnikov and Pushkin?
My guess is that Valentina found out that the two scientists on their way from Moscow were really KGB agents.
So she told the enemy agent, who intercepted the agents’ car, and killed them along with Valentina herself.
Yes. They’re probably also responsible for sabotaging the radio relay to Vostok seven.
But why do that? Why sabotage the Vostok mission?
To deprive the Soviet Union of a propaganda victory? Does seem a little drastic, I must admit.
So now we have to pretend to be two KGB agents who are pretending to be scientists from Moscow!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 48
Yes. I recommend we, um, play our cards close to our chests.
What about Laika? I mean... a talking dog? That just seems... crazy.
I know.
What do you think happened there?
That I don’t know. And I won’t until I get the chance to question her properly. But... I’ve been forbidden from speaking to her.
Maybe I could ask Captain Kozlov to sneak me in to the quarantine area? While you keep Miss Petrov occupied?
It’s worth a try. But don’t take any risks, if you get caught it will make our lives even more complicated.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 49
26. INT. QUARANTINE ROOM.
Please... can I have some water?
Not until you tell us what you’ve done with Cosmonaut Talanov!
I don’t know. Please. Give me water.
FX: THEY MOVE TO ANOTHER ROOM. ANIMALS STILL AGITATED.
We can’t withhold food and water, General. It would be inhuman.

Inhuman? This is a dog we’re talking about! A mongrel from the streets of Moscow! A laboratory specimen you wouldn’t normally think twice about putting to sleep. That’s why we sent it into Space in the first place!
But now, I think she has a.. human level of consciousness.
So we should start addressing her as Comrade Laika? Why stop there? Why not give her a parade through Red Square?
We must run more tests. Memory, intelligence. X-rays.
And in the meantime we risk the news getting out and our becoming a international laughing stock. (BEAT) You have one day, Miss Petrov. One day!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 50
27. INT. OFFICE.
I’m sorry, Doctor. But you can understand the General’s position.
Something remarkable has happened here, Miss Petrov. Something... well, frankly miraculous. And he wants it killed
to avoid embarrassment? You have to let me speak to her.
I can’t do that. But I’d like to know what you make of this. Her x-rays.
FX: X-RAY PUT ON WALL LIGHT.
Well that explains how she can talk.
It does?
Look at the larynx.
But that’s —
Human, yes.
But Laika is speaking with Cosmonaut Talanov’s voice.
- Which explains where the larynx came from. The brain’s been surgically altered too. It seems to have had sections of a human brain grafted onto the cerebral cortex.
Something used Talanov for body parts, for this dog?
Gruesome, admittedly, but an incredible scientific achievement nonetheless.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 51
But who could do this? What could do this?
Nothing of this Earth... or this time.
Right... And why?
Ah. That is the question. Wait! Presumably one of the objectives of this mission was to map the lunar surface?
Yes, of course —
Have you had the photographs developed?
No. Not yet, what with everything else, I’ve been too busy.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 52
28. INT. LABORATORY /QUARANTINE ROOM.
FX: ANIMALS SUBDUED. DOOR UNLOCKED, OPENED.
(QUIET) I warn you, if General Leonov finds out about this —
(QUIET) Yes?
I will have to inform him that you and Doctor Kalashnikov are
agents. And that you specifically requested to breach the quarantine.
He won’t find out. I only want to talk to Laika.
Laika?
Just... wait out here.
FX: ANIMALS STIRRING.
If I must. Have always hated this place, smells like an abattoir.
FX: PERI STEPS THROUGH DOOR, CLOSES IT. SILENCE.
Hello? Hello? Are you there?
Who is it?
My name is Per — Kristina. I’m a friend of the Doctor’s.
The Doctor. What do you want?
To help.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 53
Help? Yes. You can help me.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 54
29. INT. OFFICE.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
This had better be important, Miss Petrov, to drag me out of bed at midnight.
It’s important. We’ve had the photographs taken by Vostok seven developed.
We?
My idea. Just look at them.
FX: PAPERS SPREAD OVER DESK.
I am not an astronomer, craters mean nothing to me.
Look closer. This picture of the Izsak-Delport crater.
Doctor, this is the first time anybody has seen the far side of the moon, we haven’t started naming it yet.
Well I have. General?
What am I looking for? (BEAT) Wait, what’s that?
It’s not a geological feature. The Doctor thinks that small white circle might be a flying saucer.
You got me out of bed for this? This is ridiculous.
More ridiculous than your cosmonaut being replaced with a dog? More ridiculous than that dog being augmented with your missing cosmonaut’s larynx and brain?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 55
You think ‘aliens’ did this?
It’s beyond our science, and the Americans’.
So if it is a flying saucer, what do you propose we do about Zt?
I propose we go and take a closer look.
You want to go to the moon?
Yes. After all, you’ve already got everything prepared, haven’t you?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 56
30. INT. QUARANTINE ROOM
FX: GURGLING WATER.
(DRINKS) Thank you. But if you want to help... set me free.
I don’t think I can.
I’ve done nothing wrong. I just want to go. To see the sky, to breathe fresh air, to run through the snow. Like I did, when I was young.. when I begged for scraps.
But you’re not the same dog you once were. You can think now, you can talk.
And for that I should be punished? (STRUGGLES)
What did this to you? Something must have rescued you.
Release me, let me go with you, and I will tell the Doctor.
The Doctor?
He showed me kindness. I trust him. But you will have to carry
me, I don’t think I’1l be able to walk on my own.
All right, hold still.
FX: STARTS UNDOING LAIKA’S STRAPS.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 57
31. INT. HANGAR
FX: DOOR OPENS, DOCTOR, MIKHAIL AND LARISA ENTER.
How did you find out about the lunar module?
How do you think? It’s the reason why I was sent here. (FX:
MODULE) Yes, it looks serviceable enough. Intended for Vostok eight?
Yes. A rocket would carry two cosmonauts into orbit around the moon, where they could then use this module to land.
And I presume you have a rocket all fuelled up and ready to go?
We have a new Voskhod rocket prepared and on the pad, due for test launch in a couple of days’ time.
Then that sounds ideal. What do you say, Larisa? How do you fancy being the first woman to walk on the moon?
You are suggesting that I go?
Can you think of anyone more qualified? After all, you’re hardly going to let me go on my own, are you?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 58
32. INT. QUARANTINE ROOM.
FX: STRAPS RELEASED.
There you go.
FX: LAIKA JUMPS DOWN, SHAKES HERSELF.
That’s better, can stretch my legs, can — (ATTACKS PERT)
(BEING ATTACKED) What are you doing?
I must be free! Free!
FX: DOOR OPENS TO LABORATORY. ANIMALS SHRIEKING, RATTLING CAGES
IN A FRENZY.
Kristina, what’s going on, all the animals have gone crazy.
FX: LAIKA ENTERS.
Yes. Because they know that I’m here.
What the —
I recommend you run, human, if you don’t want to be torn to pieces.
Stay back. Stay back!
FX: PISTOL COCKED. PERI ENTERS.
Alexei! Don’t shoot her.
What?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB)
You do that, and the sound will bring every guard running.
FX: ALARM SOUNDS.
Bit late for that.
Then we’d better not hang around! Come on!
Yes, go. Leave me! Run!
(QUIETLY) I suppose she can’t do much damage. We can seal
place from the outside.
FX: THEY GO, LOCKING DOOR BEHIND THEM.
You think I won’t be able to find my way out?
FX: ANIMALS SHRIEKING.
this
Don’t worry, my comrades. Soon you will be free... and reborn!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 60
33. INT. HANGAR
FX: ALARM SOUNDS HERE.
That’s the quarantine alarm.
Don’t look at me, I was with you the whole time.
FX: MIKHAIL USES RADIO.
Security to quarantine section. Status report.
(VIA RADIO) It’s the animal testing laboratory, sir. Something’s happening
down there.
What? What’s happening?
FX: MOVE TO OTHER END OF CALL IN CORRIDOR.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 61
34. INT. CORRIDOR.
FX: ALARM LOUDER HERE.
Not sure, sir. When we got here the room had been sealed from the outside.
(VIA RADIO) What about the security camera?
It’s blacked out, they all seem to be — wait, Captain Kozlov is here, with Doctor Pushkin.
Sir, it appears that someone... broke into the laboratory and
released Laika.
(VIA RADIO) What?
Hearing the alarm, Doctor Pushkin and I went to investigate —
- and Laika was there. She tried to attack us.
(VIA RADIO) Laika tried to attack you?
Yes, Doctor. It was like she was rabid or something.
Sergeant Kurakin. Round up a security team.
Yes, sir. (BEAT) What for, sir?
What do you think? We’re going back in there.
FX: MOVE TO HANGAR. ALARM NOW OFF.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 62
35. INT. HANGAR
Captain, I'd be very careful if I were you. It’s possible Laika may have got free under her own steam.
What are you talking about? That dog was restrained.
If her intelligence was improved, maybe her strength was too.
Or maybe it was the work of our mysterious saboteur.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 63
36. INT. CORRIDOR
All right, Sergeant. Open the door.
FX: DOOR TO LABORATORY OPENED. SILENCE.
There’s nothing in there. All the animals have gone!
The cages are open. What could have done this?
I guess Laika was clever enough to figure out a few latches.
Then where is she now?
Here sir!
The wall panel, it’s been ripped open...
(VIA RADIO) Captain, report!
All the specimens have escaped with Laika, sir. They managed get into the ducting... they could be anywhere.
(VIA RADIO) Then track them down, captain. I want those animals caught!
FX: FADE OUT.
to
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 64
37. EXT. STREET.
FX: FADE IN. WALKING THROUGH SNOW, WIND, TRAFFIC.
Captain Kozlov still hasn’t found them?
No. But they have got a whole town to hide in.
And Laika’s intelligence to guide them.
Doctor, she threatened to tear us to pieces. She might be clever, but she’s still an animal at heart.
And now she’s got herself a gang of followers. You’1l be careful while I’m away, won’t you?
You’re not still planning on going up in a rocket?
Of course. I’m rather looking forward to it.
Haven’t we got enough to deal with down here?
No. Because whatever was responsible for what’s happening down here is up there, on the moon.
I’m amazed Miss Petrov agreed to let you go.
So was she when she saw my test results. She was reluctantly forced to admit I was the most qualified candidate. Slightly more qualified than Yuri Gagarin was, in fact.
I’d feel happier if I was going with you.
Only room for two, unfortunately. And besides, as a KGB agent, you have your own investigations to be getting on with...
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 65
38. INT. MISSION CONTROL
FX: HIVE OF ACTIVITY.
Time to launch, one hundred seconds.
What is capsule status, over?
(VIA RADIO) All systems normal. Commencing final pre-ignition checks.
Very good, Miss Petrov.
Can I speak to them?
If you’re quick.
Doctor... Kalashnikov, it’s me. Doctor Pushkin.
FX: MOVE TO CAPSULE
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 66
39. INT. CAPSULE
Kristina. Are you calling to wish me good luck?
(VIA RADIO) You just take care up there.
Have you ever known me not to? And besides, I am in the capable
hands of Miss Petrov.
(VIA RADIO) Yes, but after what happened last time —
Don’t worry. Forewarned is forearmed.
FX: MOVE BACK TO MISSION CONTROL.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 67
40. INT. MISSION CONTROL.
Time to launch, fifteen seconds.
Cosmonauts Petrov and Kalashnikov. Have a good flight.
Good luck, Doctor. And goodbye.
(VIA RADIO) Goodbye, Kristina.
Time to launch, ten seconds. Ignition key to start position.
(VIA RADIO) Ignition key to start position.
Five, four, three, two, one. Launch!
(VIA RADIO) Preliminary.
FX: SOUND OF ROCKETS VIA RADIO, THEN OUTSIDE TWO SECONDS LATER.
(VIA RADIO) Intermediate.
FX: ROCKETS DOUBLE UP.
(VIA RADIO) Main.
FX: ROCKET LAUNCHES.
We have lift off. Vostok eight has lift off!
FX: MOVE TO CAPSULE
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 68
41. INT. CAPSULE.
FX: ENGINES DEAFENING. RADIO DISTORTING.
(VIA RADIO) I repeat. Vostok eight has lift off!
(INCREASINGLY STRAINED) Accelerating. Three-g. Four-g. Five.
(VIA RADIO) Status. Miss Petrov? What is your status?
(STRAINED) I’m afraid Miss Petrov has lost consciousness... eight
g.- Nine g. Ten!
FX: MOVE TO MISSION CONTROL.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB)
42. INT. MISSION CONTROL.

ALEXEI: Hearing the alarm, Doctor Pushkin and I went to investigate —
PERI: - and Laika was there. She tried to attack us.
DOCTOR: (VIA RADIO) Laika tried to attack you?
PERI: Yes, Doctor. It was like she was rabid or something.
ALEXEI: Sergeant Kurakin. Round up a security team.
LEONID: Yes, sir. (BEAT) What for, sir?
ALEXEI: What do you think? We’re going back in there.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 62
DOCTOR: Captain, I'd be very careful if I were you. It’s possible Laika may have got free under her own steam.
LARISA: What are you talking about? That dog was restrained.
DOCTOR: If her intelligence was improved, maybe her strength was too.
LARISA: Or maybe it was the work of our mysterious saboteur.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 63
ALEXEI: All right, Sergeant. Open the door.
LEONID: There’s nothing in there. All the animals have gone!
ALEXEI: The cages are open. What could have done this?
PERI: I guess Laika was clever enough to figure out a few latches.
ALEXEI: Then where is she now?
LEONID: Here sir!
PERI: The wall panel, it’s been ripped open...
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Captain, report!
ALEXEI: All the specimens have escaped with Laika, sir. They managed get into the ducting... they could be anywhere.
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Then track them down, captain. I want those animals caught!
MIKHAIL: to
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 64
DOCTOR: Captain Kozlov still hasn’t found them?
PERI: No. But they have got a whole town to hide in.
DOCTOR: And Laika’s intelligence to guide them.
PERI: Doctor, she threatened to tear us to pieces. She might be clever, but she’s still an animal at heart.
DOCTOR: And now she’s got herself a gang of followers. You’1l be careful while I’m away, won’t you?
PERI: You’re not still planning on going up in a rocket?
DOCTOR: Of course. I’m rather looking forward to it.
PERI: Haven’t we got enough to deal with down here?
DOCTOR: No. Because whatever was responsible for what’s happening down here is up there, on the moon.
PERI: I’m amazed Miss Petrov agreed to let you go.
DOCTOR: So was she when she saw my test results. She was reluctantly forced to admit I was the most qualified candidate. Slightly more qualified than Yuri Gagarin was, in fact.
PERI: I’d feel happier if I was going with you.
DOCTOR: Only room for two, unfortunately. And besides, as a KGB agent, you have your own investigations to be getting on with...
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 65
SCIENTIST: Time to launch, one hundred seconds.
MIKHAIL: What is capsule status, over?
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) All systems normal. Commencing final pre-ignition checks.
MIKHAIL: Very good, Miss Petrov.
PERI: Can I speak to them?
MIKHAIL: If you’re quick.
PERI: Doctor... Kalashnikov, it’s me. Doctor Pushkin.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 66
DOCTOR: Kristina. Are you calling to wish me good luck?
PERI: (VIA RADIO) You just take care up there.
DOCTOR: Have you ever known me not to? And besides, I am in the capable
DOCTOR: hands of Miss Petrov.
PERI: (VIA RADIO) Yes, but after what happened last time —
DOCTOR: Don’t worry. Forewarned is forearmed.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 67
SCIENTIST: Time to launch, fifteen seconds.
MIKHAIL: Cosmonauts Petrov and Kalashnikov. Have a good flight.
PERI: Good luck, Doctor. And goodbye.
DOCTOR: (VIA RADIO) Goodbye, Kristina.
MIKHAIL: Time to launch, ten seconds. Ignition key to start position.
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Ignition key to start position.
SCIENTIST: Five, four, three, two, one. Launch!
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Preliminary.
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Intermediate.
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) Main.
MIKHAIL: We have lift off. Vostok eight has lift off!
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 68
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) I repeat. Vostok eight has lift off!
LARISA: (INCREASINGLY STRAINED) Accelerating. Three-g. Four-g. Five.
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Status. Miss Petrov? What is your status?
DOCTOR: (STRAINED) I’m afraid Miss Petrov has lost consciousness... eight
DOCTOR: g.- Nine g. Ten!
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB)
PERI: What’s happening?
MIKHAIL: Radio black-out. It is to be expected.
MIKHAIL: Page 69
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 70
MAINTENANCE: WORKER ONE
MAINTENANCE: There she goes. The first rocket to send men to the moon. And
MAINTENANCE: we were here to see it.
MAINTENANCE: WORKER TWO While repairing a leaking oil pipe. Or at least one of us was.
MAINTENANCE: WORKER ONE Still, it will be something to tell our grandchildren.
MAINTENANCE: WORKER TWO (WORKING) I can believe a man will walk on the moon, Arkady, but I cannot believe you will ever have grandchildren.
MAINTENANCE: WORKER ONE Hello there little doggy. Good boy.
MAINTENANCE: WORKER TWO Careful, he might be wild.
MAINTENANCE: WORKER ONE No, he just wants to play, don’t you? (WHISTLES ENCOURAGINGLY )
MAINTENANCE: WORKER ONE (BIT) Ow! You stinking cur!
MAINTENANCE: WORKER TWO There are more of them. (FEARFUL) No. Keep back! Back!
LAIKA: You think you can give us orders, human?
MAINTENANCE: WORKER TWO What the hell? A talking dog?
LAIKA: Oh, I can do more than talk. I can bite.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 71
MAINTENANCE: WORKER ONE & TWO
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 72
ALEXEI: And by the time the guards got there, the two men had gone.
MIKHAIL: What do you mean, ‘gone’?
ALEXEI: The dogs had dragged their bodies away, we don’t know where. watched the whole thing on the security cameras.
PERI: And you’re sure Laika did this?
ALEXEI: Oh, yes. She was leading the pack.
MIKHAIL: This has gone on long enough, sergeant. Until those animals have been destroyed, this cosmodrome is to be placed on emergency alert. No-one is to enter or leave or make any contact with the outside world.
ALEXI: Very good, sir.
MIKHAIL: And from this moment on, enforce a total curfew. No-one is to
MIKHAIL: be allowed out of their homes during the hours of darkness. Anyone found breaking the curfew will be shot!
MIKHAIL: I
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 73
FEMALE: WORKER No, I can’t let you out, Shusha. No walks tonight. No!
FEMALE: WORKER I’m sorry, but there is a curfew. Now go to bed. Go to bed.
FEMALE: WORKER Shusha. I’m telling you. Bed.
FEMALE: WORKER
FEMALE: (BEING SAVAGED) Shusha. Get down. Bad dog! Down! Down! (BANGS HEAD ON WALL, FALLS UNCONSCIOUS )
LAIKA: Leave her, my comrade. Your revenge can wait. You must join us now.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 74
PERI: Another one?
LEONID: I’m afraid so, General Leonov is trying to keep it quiet, but that’s the sixth person we’ve lost. And it’s not just the lab animals. Domestic pets, even our own guard dogs, they’ve all turned against their owners, escaped, and joined with Laika.
PERI: But why attack people?
LEONID: For food, presumably. Sorry, I didn’t mean to put you off —
PERI: No, it’s fine, I turned vegetarian a while back.
LEONID: Probably wise. You should see the stuff they feed us.
PERI: Here, have mine. Pay you back for keeping me company.
LEONID: It is a pleasure, not a duty. To spend time with the prettiest girl from Latvia.
PERI: Excuse me. I’m a highly-qualified doctor from Moscow university.
LEONID: Doesn’t stop you being a pretty girl, or from Latvia. I’m sorry. You are worried about your friend?
PERI: Wouldn’t you be? He’s been gone three days.
LEONID: Where is the capsule now?
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 75
SCIENTIST: Approaching lunar orbit. Thirty minutes to radio silence.
MIKHAIL: Status, Cosmonaut Petrov?
LARISA: (VIA RADIO) All systems normal... We’re in the wrong alignment to see the
LARISA: moon but we can see the Earth.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 76
LARISA: It’s like a blue marble in the darkness. All of history, all of creation, all the achievements of the human race, and I can cover it with one finger. I’m glad I lived to see this.
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Remember, you will have to adjust course while you are on the far side of the moon to maintain lunar orbit.
DOCTOR: Don’t worry, I’ve already made all the necessary calculations. Nothing could be simpler!
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 77
ALEXEI: Do you like taking risks, Doctor Pushkin?
PERI: No. I realise that this is breaking the curfew, but —
ALEXEI: Getting caught isn’t what worries me. It’s Laika.
PERI: Are you scared?
ALEXEI: She has managed to kill, slaughter some of my best men. So you
ALEXEI: will understand if I do not wait around.
PERI: You have the master-key?
ALEXEI: Here. The apartment of the late Valentina Cherlin. I don’t know what you hope to find, I’ve already had my men search it.
PERI: Then me taking a look can’t do any harm, can it?
ALEXEI: You have thirty minutes. Until then, Doctor.
ALEXEI: CUPBOARDS, DRAWERS.
PERI: Come on, come on. There must be something here, some clue.
PERI: (QUIET) Alexei, is that you?
LEONID: I thought I might find you here, Doctor Pushkin.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 78
PERI: What?
LEONID: You see, Kristina, I’ve worked it out. You’re not really a doctor at all. You’re a KGB agent.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 79
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Ten minutes to radio silence.
DOCTOR: We know.
LARISA: Repeating systems check. (FX: SWITCHES PRESSED) Everything normal.
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Continue checking. This is the point where Vostok Seven experienced life support failure.
LARISA: As if I didn’t know that.
DOCTOR: Can’t blame him for being paranoid. Vostok Seven was functioning perfectly before everything went wrong too.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 80
LEONID: I suspected something was odd, ever since I found you out on the steppe. So I kept an eye on you.
PERI: And I thought you were just being attentive.
LEONID: Captain Kozlov sent for you, didn’t he? That’s why you’re here. To find out why she disappeared.
PERI: So now you know why I’m here, are you going to help me?
LEONID: Of course, Kristina. If that is your name. What exactly were you hoping to find?
PERI: We believe — well, Captain Kozlov believes — that Valentina was passing on secrets to an enemy agent in the base. They were having an affair, you see.
LEONID: No. She was using Kozlov to gain access to confidential documents.
PERI: What?
LEONID: At least, that is what she wrote in her diary.
PERI: Where did you get that?
LEONID: She gave it to me before she disappeared. Told me to look after it, and give it to the KGB investigators if anything happened to her.
PERI: You didn’t tell Captain Kozlov about it?
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 81
LEONID: No. I couldn’t be sure he wasn’t the one responsible for her disappearance.
PERI: Does the diary say who the enemy agent was?
LEONID: No. It just mentions her work, and her meetings with her lover.
PERI: Captain Kozlov.
LEONID: No. Her real lover.
PERI: You?
LEONID: No, not me. She mentions in her diary, with regard to Captain Kozlov, how distasteful it was for her to be having a relationship with a man.
PERI: (PENNY DROPS) Oh no.
LEONID: What is it?
PERI: I think I’ve just worked out who the enemy agent is.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 82
LEONID: Where exactly are we going?
PERI: Mission control.
PERI: What was that?
LEONID: Laika and the other animals. They’re directly ahead of us.
PERI: And getting closer. We’ll have to find another way around.
LEONID: Back to the apartments. We can hold out there until dawn.
PERI: There isn’t time. (SEES ANIMALS) Oh no.
LEONID: We’re surrounded. We’ve walked into a trap.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 83
MIKHAIL: (VIA RADIO) Ten seconds to radio silence.
LARISA: Until we speak again, General.
DOCTOR: Right on cue!
LARISA: And any moment now, we will be passing
LARISA: into sunlight and see
LARISA: the far side of the moon for the first time.
DOCTOR: One hundred kilometres up. We should get a very good view.
LARISA: And there it is.. a world of sheer mountain ranges and shadowy canyons. So cold and white. It is beautiful!
DOCTOR: And deadly.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 84
PERI: You think you’1l be able to shoot our way out of this?
LEONID: No, but I can try.
LAIKA: Kristina.
PERI: Laika. We mean you no harm. You have to let us go.
LAIKA: You can go. You helped me. But the man... we need.
LEONID: Yeah, for food.
LAIKA: No. We have another use for you. Comrades... take him.
LEONID: No wait, wait. Please.
ALEXEI: (SHOUTS) Quick! Well don’t just stand there! Get in!
LEONID: Captain, just in time!
OVER: CAR BANGING ON WINDOWS, MONKEYS SCREECHING, DOGS SNARLING.
ALEXEI: I warned you about wandering around at night. You both in?
PERI: & LEONID Yes.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 85
ALEXEI: Then let’s get out of here.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 86
LARISA: Approaching lunar orbit insertion point. Three. Two. One.
DOCTOR: And... off.
DOCTOR: Gyroscopes confirm five degree trajectory shift.
LARISA: Then we’ve established a lunar orbit. We can rest.
DOCTOR: Not just yet. We should be approaching visual range of that alien object in the minute or so.
LARISA: You think we’ll be able to find it? It is just a mass of craters...
DOCTOR: Oh, I think so. Telescope, telescope! (FX: OPENS TELESCOPE) Should be somewhere around... oh my word.
LARISA: Doctor?
DOCTOR: I don’t believe it.
LARISA: You’ve seen it.
DOCTOR: Yes, but I don’t believe what I’ve seen. A lunar base!
LARISA: With the stars and stripes painted on the roof of the main dome. (FX: PISTOL COCKED) And now you’ve seen it, Doctor, you can never go home again.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 87
SCIENTIST: Time to radio contact.. thirty minutes.
MIKHAIL: Assuming they’re still alive.
MIKHAIL: What is the meaning of this —
PERI: I have to call the capsule. I have to warn the Doctor.
MIKHAIL: Warn him? What about?
LEONID: Larisa Petrov. She’s a spy, working for the United States!
MIKHAIL: What?
PERI: So you have to let me call the capsule!
MIKHAIL: But you can’t, it’s too late. It passed behind the moon fifteen minutes ago...
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 88
DOCTOR: I wouldn’t fire that thing in here. One bullet hole in the capsule and we’1ll both be killed.
LARISA: Then we will die together, and this will become one more failed mission for the Soviets to hush up.
DOCTOR: Of course! That’s why you sabotaged Vostok seven. To make sure the Soviets didn’t find out about the American moonbase!
LARISA: Orders straight from the White house. End the Soviet space programme once and for all. The president has promised the nation that we will win the race to the moon.
DOCTOR: But you’ve already won it! You’ve built a base there!
LARISA: Of course. He’d hardly make a promise he didn’t know he could keep.
LARISA: BADLY.
DOCTOR: What are you doing?
LARISA: Burning up our remaining fuel. Keep still, Doctor. Or I will fire.
DOCTOR: You’re altering our trajectory to a descent orbit. We’re going to crash into the moon’s surface!
LARISA: Yes, Doctor. Think of it as an honour. You will be the first man ever to die on the moon.
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 89
DOCTOR WHO: END OF PART TWO
DOCTOR WHO: THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 90

elements.text: PART THREE
58. INT. CAPSULE.
FX: REPRISE:
What are you doing?
Burning up our remaining fuel. Keep still, Doctor. Or I will fire.
But you’re altering our trajectory to a descent orbit. We’re going to crash into the moon’s surface!
FX: SWITCH PRESSED. ENGINES OFF. SILENCE.
Yes, Doctor. Think of it as an honour. You will be the first man ever to die on the moon.
And you’1ll die alongside me.
No. While you remain on board the capsule I will use the lunar lander to join my fellow patriots in Moonbase Eisenhower.
You can pilot it on your own?
I designed it, I supervised its construction. I think I am capable of landing it.
FX: ALIEN FORCEFIELD GRIPS THE CAPSULE. IT SHUDDERS AND SHAKES.
INSTRUMENTS AND ALARMS SOUND. FORCEFIELD MAKES A WHINING, HOWLING, SCREECHING SOUND, LIKE A TRACK FROM ‘METAL MACHINE MUSIC’.
(VIBRATIONS) What’s happening! What have you done!?
(VIBRATIONS) I don’t know. It’s nothing to do with me!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 91
59. INT. MISSTON CONTROL.
FX: SWITCHES PRESSED. SOUND OF STATIC.
Nothing, sir. They must have failed to establish a lunar orbit.
What does that mean?
It means either they overshot the orbital insertion point and kept on going... or the capsule has gone into a descent orbit.
You mean, it’s going to crash into the moon?
Given the choice, a quick death would be the merciful option.
Can’t you send up another rocket?
There is no other rocket. It would take weeks to prepare another mission.
What are you talking about? You’ve got loads of other rockets here, I’ve seen them!
What you have seen are Voskhod three-K-V intercontinental ballistic missile launchers. They’re not designed for spaceflight.
Kristina. You must accept it. We’ve lost him.
No. The Doctor can’t be dead. He can’t!
Captain Kozlov. As of now, Vostok missions seven and eight are to be struck from the official record. As far as anyone is concerned, they never took place!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 92
60. INT. CAPSULE.
FX: VIBRATIONS HAVE STOPPED, REPLACED BY LOW-LEVEL WARBLING AND
CREAK OF METAL.
(WAKING) What happened...?
You were knocked out. Not by me, I hasten to add.
My gun. Where is it?
In very small pieces. Hope you don’t mind, but firearms in enclosed spaces make me nervous.
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED.
We’re still on a descent orbit. I have to get to the lander!
There’s no need. Look at the altimeter.
Altitude thirty kilometres. Twenty-nine. Twenty-eight... We’re going to crash!
No. We’re going down, true enough. But something is slowing our velocity.
What? But I burned all the fuel, the retro-rockets can’t fire.
No. It’s the result of some outside influence. A force field of some kind, I should imagine. We should be grateful. If it hadn’t intervened, we’d both be dead.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 93
61. INT. CANTEEN.
FX: PLACE IS DESERTED, SOME MUSIC PLAYING.
I am sorry, Kristina, but the Doctor won’t be coming back.
No. I’ve thought him dead dozens of times before, and he’s always turned up, out of the blue. Usually with a bad joke.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Ah, Doctor Pushkin, I thought I might find you here. Sergeant, if you could return to your duties. Doctor Pushkin and I have private matters to discuss.
Yes, sir.
FX: LEONID GOES, CLOSING THE DOOR AFTER HIM.
What private matters?
I must know. How did you find out that Larisa was an American
spy?
I.. well, I suppose it doesn’t matter now. She was ina relationship with Valentina, who loved her so much, she was prepared to do anything for her.
So Valentina never had any feelings for me. I was an idiot to believe otherwise. So where is Valentina now?
I don’t know any other way to tell you this. Valentina is dead.
Dead?
Yes. I think Larisa killed her.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 94
So much for love.
FX: DOOR OPENS.
Sir.
Sergeant, I thought I told you —
Yes, sir. But it’s the animals. They... they seem to be preparing to attack.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 95
62. INT. CAPSULE.
This force field is the work of extraterrestrials?
Well, it’s beyond contemporary human technology. And we know that Vostok seven was subject to alien interference.
Because of what happened to Laika?
For it to have returned at all, its course must have been corrected when it was on the far side of the moon.
Cosmonaut Talanov could have made the correction.
No. Because by then she was already dead as a result of your sabotage.
In war, a number of... civilian casualties are to be expected.
What ‘war’?
The cold war. You remember, about a year ago, there was an international crisis due to events in the Bay of Pigs?
The Cuban Missile crisis, yes.

The world brought to the brink of nuclear conflict. And there were those in our administration who wanted to see that happen. They thought if they launched a pre-emptive strike, the Soviet Union wouldn’t be able to fight back.
But they stepped back from the brink.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 96
Because of intelligence warning them that the enemy was ready to respond in kind. If it wasn’t for people like me providing that intelligence then things would have been very different.
And that’s your justification for murdering Valentina?
I had no choice. She would’ve betrayed me, the KGB interrogators would’ve made sure of that.
Kalashnikov and Pushkin were interrogators?

With plenty of innocent blood on their hands. I did the world a favour by killing them. So you can imagine my surprise when you and “Doctor Pushkin” turned up. Made me wonder who you were working for.
And have you come to any conclusions?
I think you’re working for a third party. Because no US agent would be so foolish as to point out the location of our secret moonbase.
Speaking of which, there it is!
We’re being brought down beside it.
Yes. Right outside the front door!
FX: SOUND OF FORCE FIELD INCREASES AS IT SLOWS THEM DOWN.
Velocity still decreasing. Down to five metres a second.
Just as well, given that this capsule isn’t built for landing!
Altitude five metres. Four. Three. Two.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 97
Brace yourself!
FX: THE CAPSULE LANDS QUITE GENTLY. SOUND OF FORCE-FIELD FADES.
Oh. Well. I’ve had bumpier landings.
FX: SWITCHES CHECKED. RADIO ON.
This is agent Topaz calling Moonbase Eisenhower. (NO REPLY) This is agent Topaz calling Moonbase Eisenhower. Please
respond!
It seems they’re not “picking up”.
There must be a fault with the radio.
Sabotage that as well, did you?
No, Doctor, I did not.
FX: FEEDBACK VIA RADIO, RESEMBLING THE FORCE-FIELD NOISE.
SWITCHES IT OFF.
Ow. (BEAT) So what do you suggest we do now?
We have spacesuits. We could always pop out and knock —
FX: HATCH BEGINS TO OPEN.
Oh no. The entry hatch, it’s opening!
What?!
But if it opens while we’re on the moon, we’1ll be dead.
FX: HATCH SWINGS OPEN WITH A CREAK THEN SILENCE.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 98
Are you sure about that?
The capsule hasn’t depressurised.
No. It seems someone wants us kept alive. Come on!
FX: HE STARTS CLAMBERING OUT.
Where are you going?
Where do you think? Outside!
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 99
63. EXT. ROOF.
FX: DOOR CLANGS OPEN. WIND.
Oh great, now it’s snowing.
Sergeant, binoculars.
Here, sir.
FX: HE HANDS THEM OVER, BUSINESS WITH STRAP.
The animals have formed a perimeter around this building.
Yes. It’s almost as if they’re waiting for something.
FX: DOGS HOWL IN DISTANCE.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 100
64. EXT. STREET.
FX: DOGS HOWLING CLOSE BY.
Now it is the humans turn to know what it is to be trapped.
FX: DOG BARKS.
No, my comrade, we will not kill them. Not yet. Not until we have what we need.
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 101
65. EXT. MOON.
FX: A LIGHT BREEZE. DOCTOR CLAMBERS OUT OF CAPSULE AND LANDS ON
THE MOON. FOOTSTEPS ARE SOFT LIKE ON A SANDY BEACH.
It’s all right, Miss Petrov. The weather’s fine.
FX: SHE CLAMBERS OUT TOO.
We can breathe. There’s oxygen on the moon!
Provided for our benefit, I imagine. We’re enclosed in another force field.
Like the one that brought us down?
Yes. And it’s doing rather more than just providing us with air. By rights, standing here in direct sunlight, we should be being roasted alive. And blinded by the glare, for that matter.
So we can walk on the surface of the moon without pressure suits. It’s unbelievable. Miraculous.
Yes, it is. A rare privilege.
It’s so... bleak. Like the Negev desert, just rocks as far as the horizon. And grey, there’s no colour anywhere. But it’s beautiful. So very beautiful.
“Here is no water but only rock, rock and no water and the cracked earth, ringed by the flat horizon only.”
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 102
66. EXT. ROOF.
(VIA TANNOY)
(INTO TANNOY) Attention all residents of the Baikonur Cosmodrome. Until further notice, the curfew is extended to twenty-four hours. You are to remain in your homes. I repeat, remain in your homes.
FX: TANNOY OFF.
It’s mostly dogs and cats, with some monkeys. Can’t see Laika
anywhere, though.
She must be out there somewhere.
Then where is she? And how is she giving them instructions?
They just seem to understand what she wants, by instinct.
.Like in the animal testing laboratory.
What concerns me is what she wants with us. What was it she
said? “We have another use for you.”
Oh no. I think I might have an idea what it is.
FX: ROOF DOOR PULLED OPEN.
Where are you going?
(LEAVING) To check something.
Then I’m coming with you.
Can’t get enough of me, huh?
THE SPACE RACE by Jonathan Morris (FINAL-NB) Page 103
67. EXT MOON.
